comment._content: This appears to be a throng of well wishers from New York City's large Italian-American population, along with members of the press, awaiting the arrival of Ernesto Nathan (1848-1921), the former mayor of Rome (1907-1914), who arrived in New York aboard the Italian steamer Stampalia of the La Veloce Line, on May 25, 1914. There were so many delegates on hand from leading Masonic organizations in New York State, and from the Italian Societies in New York City to greet Signor Nathan's arrival that when the ship came alongside the pier at the foot of West Thirty Fourth Street, the wooden gangplank bridge creaked uncomfortably, and officials ordered the large crowd back to the area shown in the above photograph to prevent an accident. Signor Nathan was appointed by King Victor Emmanuel to be Royal Italian Commissioner representing Italy to the 1915 Panama-Pacific Exposition in San Francisco, and honorary Minister Plenipotentiary. Nathan departed New York City on the afternoon train to Washington, DC, where he met with President Wilson the following day, before traveling on to San Francisco. [1] [2] [3]

comment._content: Nathan was arriving to supervise the construction of Italy's exhibit to the fair. The following year, he came for the opening of the fair, arriving in New York on the ocean liner America from Italy. The Bain collection has 2 photos from that arrival, too: Nathan was a controversial figure. Born in England of Jewish parents, he went on to be mayor of Rome for 6 years. His appointment to head Italy's representation in the Pan-American Exposition brought on a boycott of the fair by a number of U.S. Catholic organizations, who denounced him as anti-Catholic. In his defense, he said he opposed the Catholic political party in Italy, not the religion or its adherents.
